I kept dreading when I would play this game. I knew just by looking at it that I would be mildly bored by it for it's 40 short minutes of play time, and you know what?  I was right in dreading it.  Voices from the Sea is another interactive Japanese-culture-inspired interactive novel. It follows an angsty boy named... Cantus, who lives on an island and is plagued by all the 'noise' in his world, like his mom telling him to make more friends, or a kid named Garrio poking fun of him. Honestly, Cantus comes across as a bit of a pr*** in the scenes away from the ocean. Like a moody teenager pouting about how life sucks and no one understands him.  But, unbeknownst to our unlikeable protagonist, he meets a mysterious girl from the ocean named Maris, who is... just strange. Not really charming or enlightening. Just strange. She tries desperately to make him smile in the 7 days they talk, but all of their scenes are as awkwardly-written as everything else in the game. There are SOME points where they start talking like real people (about, you know, real feelings and relationships instead of angsty bullsh**), but they're soon cut off by the pretentious narration. And the blackout with a sentence-ending to close each day is the icing on the pretentious cake.  The game does have a little quality put into the backgrounds, but the actual animation and music are just... bland and cheap-looking. Sure, Everlasting Summer is one of my favorite interactive novels and it looks very similar to Voices from the Sea, but it's the story that made Everlasting Summer such an engrossing game. And Voices from the Sea just doesn't have it. A kid is depressed about vague stuff in life, a girl talks to him in some cringey and awkward scenes, and he realizes he loves his mom out of nowhere at the end... even with how sh**ty he's been treating her up to that point. It just doesn't add up.   But, wait! Voices from the Sea does involve interactivity! REAL interactivity! As in, you can make decisions in this game! Guess what you can choose?  What f***ing seashell looks best.  Are you f***ing kidding me? What is this bullsh**? It's not implemented into the story, save for the end, and it's just a mindless bit where you stare at the same blank screen (Even though you might be moving right or left, according to the game) and you just pick a seashell for the day. It has no impact on the plot. It's just there.  Voices from the Sea is as pretentious as it is artless. As I expected, I was mildly bored while playing, but all those little irritating things culminated into an overall unpleasant 40 minutes that I feel were honestly wasted on this bland interactive novel. It might be free, but I heavily recommend you spend your time on an actually well-written interactive novel, like Everlasting Summer. As for Voices from the Sea, I'm giving it a 3/10. There's a little quality here, but it's so bogged down by the rest of the bullsh** in this game, that I cannot see myself playing it again ever.

Voices from the Sea is a short visual novel that has reasonably good artwork throughout. It's heavily reliant on blue and white for most of its color scheme. Depending on your reading speed, you’re looking at a 40 to 60 minute experience.  The story has plenty of funny moments and goes for charm and sweetness when the characters aren’t being goofy. You can expect to be a bitter, lonely 13 year old male, at least in the beginning. I strongly suggest taking the dialogue choice that isn’t the seashell one first to maximize your experience since the latter is the critical path.  You can also expect a lot of seashells by the seashore. Multiple playthroughs will allow you to collect every single seashell if you desire them all.  Finally, I want anime eyes. I would be able to see in the dark so well.

This game is absolutely amazing. This is the first VN game I've ever played and I want to play more VN's if their stories are as interesting as this.   In Voices from the Sea you are a young boy named Cantus, an anti-social kid who has problems with his mother and the people around him, and one day you meet a strange girl named Maris while on the beach and she becomes your friend. Maris wants to cheer Cantus up, so she vows to make him smile within seven days. Each day they have a different discussion and each day ends with you collecting a seashell and giving it to Maris.   The story is beautiful and I personally was able to connect with Cantus (due to the fact that I'm an anti-social as well and I'm only one year older than him, about to turn 15 in a month myself although my age is irelevent). The only qualm I have with it is that at the end of every day you have to collect a seashell, and I wish that there was more ways to interact with Maris. But other then that, I HIGHLY RECOMMEND this to everyone. I hope you enjoy this game like I did. Game Time: 1 Hour. Rating: 9.5/10 Deserves an Anime or OVA series
